title: 104_s1939
content: The Act may be cited as the "Livestock Market Revitalization Act of 1996" and addresses captive supply. The Livestock Market Revitalization Act of 1996 defines captive supply as livestock acquired for slaughter by a packer under specific arrangements. The Act also requires the Secretary to provide an annual report on the number and volume of livestock marketed or slaughtered in the United States. The Livestock Market Revitalization Act of 1996 requires the Secretary to provide information on livestock transactions, including regional and local markets, ensuring confidentiality and reporting of a significant share of transactions. Additionally, it includes provisions for reporting captive supply transactions within 24 hours. The Livestock Market Revitalization Act of 1996 mandates the Secretary to disclose information on livestock transactions, including captive supply transactions, within 24 hours for public access. SEC. 3. MONITORING OF ANTITRUST AND ANTICOMPETITIVE BEHAVIOR AMONG PACKERS AND STOCKYARDS. The Secretary is required to review and monitor antitrust and anticompetitive behavior among packers, stockyard owners, market agencies, and dealers to ensure compliance with Federal law and enhance competitiveness. Results of the review must be reported to Congress, the Attorney General, and the public. The Secretary of Agriculture must review and monitor antitrust and anticompetitive behavior in the livestock industry to ensure compliance with Federal law. A report assessing resource needs for this task must be submitted to Congress within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture must review and monitor antitrust and anticompetitive behavior in the livestock industry to ensure compliance with Federal law. A report assessing resource needs for this task must be submitted to Congress within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include a request for additional funding for section 407(h) of the Act and assess progress in implementing additional monitoring activities in geographical procurement markets. SEC. 4. COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION OF MARKETING INFORMATION. Section 204(g) of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 is amended to require the Secretary to provide price information at the point of sale, on a regular basis, electronically to the public, and collect data on contract pricing related to captive supply in the meat industry. The amendment requires the Secretary to provide consistent pricing information in the meat industry and report weekly imports of cattle and meat products into the US. SEC. 5 of the Agricultural Fair Practices Act of 1967 is amended to include provisions for cooperative bargaining, ensuring good-faith negotiations and non-discrimination among producer cooperatives. SEC. 6 focuses on labeling requirements for meat and meat food products. SEC. 6 amends the Federal Meat Inspection Act to require labeling information including country of origin for imported meat products. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a national commission to modernize the livestock industry and address consumer demand for red meat. The commission will analyze costs and benefits, make recommendations on value-added livestock products, antitrust impact on cattle prices, meat grading system, and refunds under the Beef Research and Information Act. The commission must submit a report by January 1, 2000. The study results will be reported to the House and Senate Agriculture Committees.
